Expectation1: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation1: A procedural hearing on a minor matter can easily be postponed if necessary.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: The station is set to lock its doors in ten minutes.
Story: I glance at the clock on my office wall, heart pounding. The courthouse is only a few blocks away, but so is the polling station. My client’s procedural hearing is scheduled in fifteen minutes—a minor matter, one that could easily be postponed. Still, I know my duty as a lawyer: to be present, to represent, to show my client that their case matters, no matter how small. But the polling station closes in ten minutes, and I haven’t voted yet. Civic duty tugs at me; I believe in the process, in the power of a single vote. I promised myself I wouldn’t miss it this year. My phone buzzes with a reminder from the court, while my mind races with the weight of both roles. I can’t be in two places at once. My client expects my presence; my country expects my participation. I stand in my office, keys in hand, torn between the courtroom and the ballot box, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
